ThingDef.label: humerus
ThingDef.description: The upper arm bone. It runs from the scapula to the elbow.

ThingDef.label: radius
ThingDef.description: One of two forearm bones. Aids in wrist articulation and is connected to the humerus above.

ThingDef.label: ulna
ThingDef.description: The thinner of the forearm bones. Aids in arm rotation in conjunction with the wrist and is connected to the humerus above.

ThingDef.label: femur
ThingDef.description: The longest, heaviest, and strongest bone in the body. It supports stability and is weight bearing.

ThingDef.label: patella
ThingDef.description: The patella, or knee cap, assists in the extension capacity of the leg.

ThingDef.label: tibia
ThingDef.description: The second largest bone in the body. It aids in bearing the weight of the human body.

ThingDef.label: fibula
ThingDef.description: This bone, in conjunction with the tibia, assists in the stability of the ankle joint.

ThingDef.label: rib bone
ThingDef.description: Along and slender, yet hardy bone which supports the entire ribcage and creates the protective skeletal structure of the chest.

ThingDef.label: vertebrae
ThingDef.description: A strong and hardy bone, comprised of protein, collagen, and minerals, especially calcium. It supports the spinal column.

ThingDef.label: sacrum
ThingDef.description: The sacrum is a shield-shaped bony structure that is located at the base of the lumbar vertebrae and that is connected to the pelvis.

ThingDef.label: coccyx (tailbone)
ThingDef.description: Also known as the tail bone, it is part of the "tripod". The tripod is a group of internal body parts that provide weight-bearing support in the seated position
